content.description:
Start off moving right on jugs towards first bolt. After reaching the first bolt, begin upwards. Make a mildly scary big move off of an undercling to more big holds and jug haul to the short but powerful and crimpy crux at the 3rd or 4th bolt, pulling to the alcove full of fossilized poop flow. You'll know what I mean when you see it... Either climb into the alcove and rest or just follow the lip to the anchors.

FYI, crawling out of the alcove to reach the anchors is a bit spooky. But the rest stance is sooo nice.

If anyone knows the FA, the actual length, or any other good bits of info, let me know.
content.protection:
4 or 5 bolts. 2 Rap bolt anchors.

It'd be smart to stick clip the first bolt.
content.location: The short line in the back of the obvious cave at the middle of the wall.

content.description: Fun, easy climbing with a low crux. Those allergic to runouts and sharp rock might not pick this one as a winner, but it's a good, easy route. Takes a hard left at the low-angle-the routes are so close here, it's tough to tell them apart.
content.location:
4th Route from the left. 2nd after the bulge that is

K-1

.

content.description: Very featured holds abound for the first two thirds of the line, followed by vertical pinches and side-pulling fun near the top.
content.location: Starts up a 8 foot or so vertical section followed by an immediate easing of the angle.

content.description: This fun moderate starts on the slab to the left of K-6. A tricky move leads to an overhanging arete section on powerful liebacks. The angle leans back as you head to the anchors on K-6.
content.location: The first route to the left of K-6's overhanging scoop.

content.description: The route start off on a low-angle slab with holds in all the right places. Features get slimmer and slimmer and the angle steeper and steeper as the route continues. At the headwall the moves get really interesting and fun. A few tricky moves up to the horizontal cracks gets you through the crux and to the jug-pulling to the anchors.
content.location:
Just to the right of

Czech Frogs Say Qua

on the corner between the left and right sides of Kelly's Rock.

content.description: Low angle featured face
content.location: Right most route on the slab just to the right of Rending of Garments and Gnashing of Teeth.

content.description: This is now the farthest East (Left) route on Kelly's Wall. Look for this route traversing above the lip where K-1 goes up. Starts off with some fun pinches, gets slabby for a moment and then finishes steeper with a 5.6+ move to the chains.
content.protection: Quickdraws. Nice chain anchors at the top. Thin chain though, bring something to TR through.
content.location: The farthest left route on the wall, past the overhanging K-1.

content.description: Bouldery.
content.location: The arete right of Hubris corner. Easy to TR when lowering off Hubris.

content.description: Delicately move up the slab to the first roof and quickly encounter the crux, moving left on marginal holds to a good side-pull.  Make the clip to avoid a nasty fall onto the ledge below, then move up and right through the slot and under some bird crap to a step out left for the chains.  Fun moves and great position.
content.location: In the alcove to the right of Hubris are two 5.12 climbs.  This is the right of the two which climbs through a roof on orange rock.

content.description:
Easy face with good feet to the first bolt.  Shuffle back and forth on the flat slab to keep the grade reasonable.

Transition to the first short roof where the rock turns pricklier.  Clip a couple of bolts and then head slightly left.

Last bolt before the anchor is on the flat face to the right of the rib and is easy to miss if you're cruising comfortably.

Named for the dark and trendy martini lounge (and drink) in Los Angeles:

Update:  alas...the Liquid Kitty is closed.

thelosangelesbeat.com/2016/â€¦

"The intoxicating darkness that is Liquid Kitty"
content.protection:
9 lead bolts.  First three are 1/2" with Fixe hangers (mega bomber).

Anchor is a set of Fixe Double Ring and Chain anchors.

All stainless, all the time.
content.location:
Located just left of JB's

Wet My Whistle

.  This should do the trick, Jeff.

Rappel/lower off.

content.description: Climb slightly to the right off the top of the boulder.  Move straight up from there on small slippery holds out of the scoop.  Easier climbing to the chains.
content.location: Starts off the right side of the boulder.

content.description:
This route is named "k-8" because it originally was the eighth route from the left side.   Now it about the 11th or 12th, so things have changed a little.

Anyway, Todd Goss calls this "one of the best routes in Utah".  Wow... strong statement!   However, I am hard pressed to argue with him - I can't think of another one at the 11b grade that is as good as this.

Great pockets and edges through a couple of roofs, everything but the kitchen sink on this line.
content.location: Starts right on top of the big boulder in the middle of the crag.   there are about 10 lines left of the big boulder.   2 lines leave the top of the boulder, this is the right most of the two.

content.description: Starts and finishes on slab.  The hard part is the bold climbing to pass the diagonal seam midway up.
content.location: Just right of K-6.  Last route out of the gravel on grey rock before the boulder.

content.description: Another classic 11b up an intimidating overhanging scoop.   This route starts with some thin slabbing up the scoop, and then a series of utterly perfect holds lead up through the overhang.  Super fun, excellent stone, great line!
content.location: Pretty easy to spot- start at the big boulder on the left side of the crag.   K-8 leaves from the top of the boulder.   The next 2 lines left of there are 5.12.  The next line left of them is K-6, and is obvious as it pulls through the left side of a big overhanging scoop.

content.description:
Slab and Steep?

Scurry up the batter-like slab to the steep head wall. Side-pulls, crimps, and a jug or two finish it out. A bit pumpy and rather interesting, to say the least.
content.protection: Six bolts to a rap anchor.
content.location:
K-5 sits in the middle of the wall sharing its start w/

Tag Team

content.description:
A seemingly casual jaunt up featured limestone quickly turns to puzzlement at the third bolt, when holds disappear and you are left with a delicate, tricky move or two through the crux.

Subsequent to the puzzlement is a small roof with a little bit of technical positioning trickery required to see it through to the chains.
content.location:
First line to the left of a large, almost horizontal pod just off the ground. Found near the middle of the left side of

Kelly's Rock

(the part to the left of the large boulder at the base).

content.description: This route has a very different feel than all the other nearby ones. Lots of smooth, but positive holds. It is a little more bouldery than the routes to the left, with a bunch of fun moves.
content.protection: 2 bolts to chains. The first bolt is high, and it looks like there used to be a bolt down lower. A lead fall in certain places could result in decking. A stick-clip is a good idea here.
content.location:
This is the 7th route from the left. Just to the right of

The Awakening

.

content.description: Steep and stout climbing up the short bulging face. An intimidating line from the ground, big hidden holds dispersed through the water runnels give plenty of opportunities to finish without your face in your hand. An ok line for the area with some fun, interesting climbing.
content.protection: Three bolts to a rap anchor.
content.location:
This route is the left-most, short, steep face at

Kelly's Wall

.

content.description: Start on Just This Finish on Zealot. Long Power endurance boulder problem. Both cruxes, harder than Just This.
content.protection: Bolts. Long draw on 2nd bolt of Just This helps prevent drag.

content.description: Hard pocket pulls off the deck. The angle eventually relents, but not the technicality. A stick clip is advantageous.
content.location: In the alcove right of Zealot.

content.description: This is a really nice route that doesn't see as much traffic as the other 11's at Kelly's, but worth doing.   Start by climbing the dihedral to its top, then head a bit left, working upward toward a large ledge below an overhang.   Clip the bolt in the overhang and the crux begins.   After clipping the next bolt, its pretty cruiser, but really fun holds.   Nice long route, bring a 60M rope for sure.
content.location: Locate the cave in which Zealot, 12c and Just This, 13a begin.   Hubris is about 20 feet to the right starting in a left facing corner.

content.description: Start up K-8, then follow pockets and slopers diagonally to the right to join K-9 for its last 4 bolts.  You skip the cruxes of both of those routes, but don't let the grade fool you!
content.location: Starts on top of the boulder.  Same as for K-8, finishes on K-9.

content.description: Start by climbing up the steep slab on orange rock to reach the overhang.  Get a good shake and punch it to pull the lip (crux).   There's a good trick kneebar beta that really makes this not so tough.  Gain a stance above the roof and follow positive runnels to the end.  Fun!
content.location: Just to the left of Mayhem.   On the far right side of the crag.

content.description: Climb the low angle slab, sharing the start with Rending of Garments, 5.10a.   At the point where the wall gets steeper and the bolt lines split, take the right route up into the orange rock.
content.location: Start at the base of a gray slabby buttress to the right of Czech Frogs Say Qua.   Furthest climb to the right at the main section of Kelly's before heading up to the cave.

content.description:
This route starts up a steep slab with tons of foot placements. If you don't know what to do, look down and move your feet. After a few bolts it gets slabby and very easy, then leads into a slight bulge that is pretty fun.

The rock quality is great. The limestone at Kelly's Rock is bullet-hard, and somewhat sharp. Just go easy on the hands, and work the feet.
content.location: There are 3 routes between "Wet My Whistle" and "The Awakening". This is the middle one.

content.description: Sharp and slabby, this technical jaunt climbs an ever-steepening face over some vicious terrain. Difficult and hard to read, the top will keep you thinking. Exposed and a bit desperate.
content.protection: Six to eight draws to an anchor.
content.location:
This is the right-most route in the middle section of

Kelly's Rock

. It is directly right of

Gnashing of Teeth

.

content.description: Climb into the large hueco and make a few technical moves trending up and left.  The area 10 feet or so above the pod is the crux.   Continue up and left for increasingly easier climbing to the shuts.   Avoid going too far left or you'll find yourself on the 5.12b route that's nearby.   Great climb!
content.location: Locate the large keyhole hueco about 15 feet to the right of the large boulder used to gain access to K-8.  This route starts at the hueco.

content.description:
A short, but fun little route with lots of interesting features to grab. Lots of positive jugs lead into some sloping side-pulls and stemming in a large runnel. At the top the route changes personality to a short slabby section.

Todd Goss gives this route 3/3 stars in his guidebook. This is a great route in my opinion as well.
content.location: This is the 6th route from the left side. It is just to the left of K-3

content.description: Easy climbing on positive jugs for 2-3 bolts, then things get really smooth. It would be very easy to go to the left on Wet My Whistle, or the one to the right (since these climbs are all very close together). Some thin slabby climbing lead to an easier low-angle section up to the 5th bolt. After that, you need to overcome a slight bulge. Some fun moves are found here. Then it's some thinner moves to the chains.
content.location:
This route is sandwiched tightly in between

Wet My Whistle

and

Unknown 2

.

content.description: Start on top of the block and move left.  Edges lead to difficult arete.
content.location: Left of K-8.  Move left off the top of the boulder.

climbs.name: A Force To Be Reckoned With

content.description: Fun, easy climbing up a large featured runnel.
content.location:
This route is located between Demagogue and

The Awakening

.
